comments.commentBody:
{headdesk} Sorry, guys. I have no control over what comes out of that widget.

One more time: If you want to download the correct puzzle, *please* do so from the main puzzle page, here:

http://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/index.html

I see that Deb's blog has the Sunday Oct. 19 puzzle on tap.
Constructed by Patrick Blindauer no less!

Regards to all from Northern Canada
WVC

But consider: for decades now, funding for educaton in the arts in American schools and universities has all but evaporated. The understanding  - much less appreciation - of Art has become a dwindling pastime of an ever smaller minority of Americans. I actually feel sorry for people like Weisenfeld who probably have no capacity to grasp even the concept of artisitic freedom and it's important role in a free society. In this case, in their obsessive reactionary zeal to be apologists for Israel, they are trampling on that freedom and are accomplishing nothing more than exposing themselves for the bigots they really are.
Now I really want to see it.
How would you know without seeing it?
It's not a hate piece.
Sadly the Met produces such a  hate piece. How the  principles have left the opera house.

By coincidence, this controversy flares up just as I am reading about the history of violence and peace-making in Northern Ireland during the last decades of the twentieth century.  I have no recollection of street protests against the many films and other productions that took agents on both sides seriously (or that sentimentalized them), although their mutual murders of innocents counted in the hundreds even in "quiet" years.  No one who knows the history of Irgun's killings in Palestine can make sweeping categorical judgments about which human acts and agents are beyond the scope of artistic inquiry.  Of course, it always help to go whole heartedly into these things when you protect yourself from such knowledge.  That applies to people who drop bombs and never have to confront their actions or face much risk.  God bless our troops. That the Klinghofers are inconsolable is understandable; that their pain is exploited to make political statements about Israeli killings in Gaza is shameful.          David Yitzchak

Wonderful response that cuts to the core. Thank you for stating it so well.

Mr. Klinghoffer's murder was the first time I felt personally threatened for the mere fact of being who I am: it was early days then, when car bombs, kidnappings, intentional plane crashes, and beheadings had not yet become routine events.

No circumstance justifies the terrorist act of murder; but the task of bringing peace to Israelis and Palestinians demands that we listen and refrain from demonizing. Working towards a two-state solution and a real and responsible peace requires this of us.

Both Israelis and Palestinians have suffered greatly and lost hugely: in lives, homes, neighborhoods, security, access, health, education -- everything that makes a life pleasurable and worthwhile. Seeking to drown out the cries of the other will only serve to perpetuate this condition and will never bring peace. It is long past time that we listened better.
But you do enjoy reading about them and entering a post in the discussion!  Strange.
And bravo to you for going and bravo to the protestors for making their views known.

I am very proud as a Jewish-American to say that I have tickets for one of the upcoming performances, and am looking forward to seeing this opera on an important subject by one of our greatest composers. Bravo to the Met for having the courage to present this production.

Can you explain to me, in precise terms, why it's such an offensive piece? I have yet for anyone on your side of the argument cogently and dispassionately explain why or how the story celebrates terrorism. Other than simply telling the story, how does it specifically celebrate anti-semitism? I mean to ask this as respectfully as possible. I really would like to understand. Because at the moment, all I've heard is "it's bad" "it's in poor taste" But based off of reading the libretto, I'm hard-pressed to understand your point of view. But I'd like to better understand.

Read closely, up to 20% are caused by Adenovirus. That is only a single type of virus. The vast majority of conjunctivitis is caused by a virus, not 80% bacterial.

The 5 days you wait with a sore throat are the same 5 days whether or not you're taking an antibiotic. The antibiotic isn't treating your throat, merely your mind; thank you for reinforcing the point of this article.

Joe Mando,

Actually, according to Dr. Caroll's previous article, the five days of waiting are probably not the same, thanks to the placebo effect. The issue with antibiotics is the potential negative impact their overuse has.

I agree with you, Debbie, that we do need to be concerned with overuse of antibiotics and I certainly don't want one wiping out my gut bacteria unless it's necessary.
And many antibiotics can have very unpleasant side effects.
However, I just feel that the first line of attack on overuse must be waged against antibiotic use in the food supply, not on little kids with pinkeye.

This is absurd. Advocate some type of rapid culturing and a delayed antibiotic prescription, fine, but this is bordering on anti-vaccine paranoia.

Up to 20% of conjunctivitis could be caused by a virus, so we should let at least 80% of small children suffer longer while continuing to rub discharge on everything they see?

Basically, because physicians could misdiagnose and patients don't understand they're still contagious, physicians should not prescribe antibiotics? I'll take my antibiotics when I have very high levels of unexplained swelling and pain in my throat, you can sit in pain for another 5 days waiting for the second round of testing after the first one comes back negative.
If you note the LOGIC of my post, you will see that I am _not_ advocating what you selectively quote.  Read closer.

Elegance incarnate.

Sorry to lose him...I always loved seeing his new clothes and on gorgeous women. A wise man about beauty and value.

The separatist, while they may be pro-Russian, are actually all from Ukraine and were born there. At the time they were born Ukraine was still an SSR. Most were born  when the country was still part of the USSR> But they are all Ukrainians. The head of the Separatist government in both Oblasts were born in Ukraine and are native Ukrainians. They simply don't want to live under the Kiev government nor do they want to be members of the EU or beholden to the IMF

I am surprised and disappointed that the writer displays a lack of understanding in her description of "classical conditioning." techniques in animal training.  Classical conditioning is not the use of aversive (the mention of "pressure lifted") stimuli to train tasks.  It works at a subconscious level, to embed associations.  One might use CC to get a horse to board a trailer calmly (trailer equals treats and praise), but training a horse to respond to signals from rein, bit, or knee is operant conditioning.  Or often something far more aversive, from what I have seen in common horse training.
No.

Right. Then there was President George Herbert Walker Bush, former head of the CIA. Wonder if daily Russian news reports during the Bush presidency regularly, without fail, and unremittingly, made sure their readership knew what this patrician politician was really up to.

Finally they're reporting the Cluster bombs because the Ukraine Gov't has been shooting them off for months now and people were interviewed confirming the use of them with photos, videos and doctor reports.

To confirm, you 'doubt that the Rada will be democratic', even after elections?  Specifically what do you think democracy is?  Is cheering for a Russian invasion of Ukraine an exemplar of supporting democracy?

I will never forget the day I saw Oscar de la Renta dashing across the street outside Bloomingdale's in New York--this was in the early 60s.  How could you miss that tall, handsome man.  And, oh, he was so elegantly dressed.  Perfect in every way.  What a presence.  He will be so missed.
Yes, you're right.  Let's just drop the whole Bill of Rights.  No need for constitutional protection of disfavored minorities... we'll just wait for social consensus.

Having made this point myself many times, I have to support the President in this. It is understandable that decent people would be impatient for universal recognition of gay marriage. But look at what happened with Roe v. Wade. If the Supreme Court imposes gay marriage on the socially backwards states, the Republicans will seize upon the issue and we risk the same kind of red state resentment that is currently depriving women of the right to abortion.

Younger people overwhelmingly support gay marriage and even older people are changng their attitudes. Victory is inevitable. Let's not give Republicans the wedge issue they want: the wise and prudent strategy, and the one that is likely to yield the best results, is one of delayed gratification.

Pseudo-legalese babble aside, Timothy just perfectly exemplified the old soviet and modern Russian political tactic of whataboutism, or discrediting the opponent's position by asserting the opponent's failure to act consistently in accordance with that position, without directly refuting or disproving the opponent's initial argument. Double hypocrisy?

Ukraine is terrible, isn't it?

Using cluster bombs and other such indiscriminate weapons are never acceptable. Even while being subjected to a proxy insurrection by Russian militants pretending to be Ukrainians in an attempt to destabilize the country after conducting a farcical "referendum" on joining Russia under the shadow of an invading army, using weapons like that is never justified.

No one in this situation has clean hands.

It's too bad for the rest of us that those Americans who are so fearful of Ebola, vaccines, and science (not to mention gays, blacks, Arabs and Latinos) as to build walls around themelves and thereby keep the truth from hitting them in the face don't remain inside those walls on Election Day.
No illegal nationalist coup, no rebellion in the east. It's that simple.

CR: Try a psychoanalytically-oriented therapist, who still are concerned about the "client-therapist relationship." More specifically, seek a "relationally-oriented psychoanalysis" who believe in the power and efficacy of uman relationships. This is a group that is not swayed by Big Data.
